metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Architectural Antiquities of Great Britain. Pt. 24. Vol. 3
metadata.label: Alternate Title

metadata.value: John Britton, the antiquarian and topographer, began work on his series of antiquary drawings, Architectural Antiquities of Great Britain, in the most accurate and detailed way. He went about this by documenting detailed areas of his subject parts and ornaments. This volume in specific details the Roslyn Chapel of Scotland. Britton was one of the first to focus on the details of the Roslyn Chapel in published engravings. This particular copy, as seen by the inscription on the top right corner, is from John Britton himself to the Royal Institution of Scotland in 1829.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Presented to the Royal Institution of Edinburgh by the author. April11. 1829.
metadata.label: Inscription

metadata.value: As the inscription states, this copy was gifted to the Royal Institution of Edinburgh from Britton in 1829. It also has a stamp from the Edinbrugh College of Art Library.
metadata.label: Provenance Notes

canvases.label: An Essay Towards an History and Description of Roslyn Chapel, Scotland, pl.7

metadata.value: An Essay Towards an History and Description of Roslyn Chapel, Scotland
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Architectural Antiquities of Great Britain. Pt. 24. Vol. 3
metadata.label: Alternate Title

metadata.value: John Britton, the antiquarian and topographer, began work on his series of antiquary drawings, Architectural Antiquities of Great Britain, in the most accurate and detailed way. He went about this by documenting detailed areas of his subject parts and ornaments. This volume in specific details the Roslyn Chapel of Scotland. Britton was one of the first to focus on the details of the Roslyn Chapel in published engravings. This view is of the apprentice column, named after the story of an apprentice who completed the column without seeing the original in which he was meant to imitate while his master was away viewing the model. When his came back, the master struck down the apprentice with a mallet in a jealous fit. It was then said that the master's face was carved at the other end of the chapel forever gazing on the apprentice column. This engraving of the apprentice column and those surrounding it was created by J. Burnett from a drawing by Joseph Gandy. Britton then dedicates the page to Sir Walter Scott "Whose various poetical, & critical writings entice much Genius and Knowledge".
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: An Essay Towards an History and Description of Roslyn Chapel, Scotland, pl.7
